SENT.plain: BACKGROUND AND PURPOSE: In major cerebral arterial steno-occlusive diseases, there can be remarkably decreased hemodynamic reserve without marked neurological impairments
In such settings, it is not known whether the neural activity is well maintained or disturbed according to the severity of cerebral ischemia
The present study was therefore undertaken to examine the neural activity under mild cerebral ischemia resulting from major cerebral arterial occlusion
METHODS: Seven patients with minor neurological impairment as well as either unilateral internal carotid artery or middle cerebral artery occlusion were studied
The severity of the cortical ischemia was assessed by measuring regional cerebral blood flow (rCBF) with positron emission tomography
The change in neural activity in the ischemic brain was then evaluated by means of somatosensory evoked magnetic field with magnetoencephalography

RESULTS: The rCBF in the primary sensory area and the strength of the initial component of somatosensory evoked magnetic field (N20 m) were significantly reduced (P<0.01) and the second component (P30 m) was significantly augmented (P<0.05) in the lesioned cerebral hemisphere as compared with the nonlesioned hemisphere
The asymmetry indexes for N20 m were positively correlated (r=0.78) and those for P30 m were inversely correlated (r=-0.92) with asymmetry indexes for rCBF

CONCLUSIONS: In patients with either unilateral internal carotid artery or middle cerebral artery occlusion and minor neural impairments, there was a reduction of afferent signal and an augmentation of the secondary response of the neurons in the primary sensory area
This showed correlation with the severity of cortical ischemia
